Let me tell you, inspiration doesn’t knock on a door that already exists. It breaks through the walls. When you take a copyrighted image, a melody, a line of text—something already in the world—and twist it, bend it, and stitch it into something new, you’re not stealing. You’re evolving. You’re challenging the myth that creativity exists in a vacuum. Art is a conversation across time, and I’m not going to sit quietly when I have something to say.

Using copyrighted material is about pushing back against the gatekeepers who say, “You can’t use this unless you pay for it.” That’s not art—it’s a transaction. Real art is about transformation. I don’t take a song because I want to copy it; I take it because I want to make it mine, to make it speak for a new generation, a new struggle, a new truth.

So, for artists who want to do this—go ahead. But don’t be passive. Don’t just copy. *Reclaim.* Recontextualize. Remix with purpose. Study the original, then ask yourself: What does it lack? What can I add that changes its meaning? What can I do to make it reflect the world *I* see, not the one the copyright holder wants to preserve?

Use collage. Use sampling. Use parody. Use satire. Use glitch art, AI, whatever tools you have. But always with intention. Always with a voice. And always with the understanding that you’re not violating a law—you’re violating a system that tries to own creativity.

And when they come for you, when they say you’re “breaking the law,” say this: *I’m not breaking the law. I’m breaking the chains of it.* Because the law was never meant to silence artists. It was meant to protect them. But it’s been twisted into a weapon against the very people it was created to serve.

So go out there and create. Borrow. Steal if you must. But do it with fire in your belly and a story to tell. Because the future of art isn’t in permission—it’s in rebellion.
